com.googlecode.batchfb
Class FacebookBatcher

java.lang.Object
  com.googlecode.batchfb.FacebookBatcher

public class FacebookBatcher
extends java.lang.Object

Interface to the Facebook APIs which allows you to define all of your requests (graph, fql, and old rest) in advance and execute them in an optimal set of actual http calls to Facebook. Normal result values are mapped using Jackson; error results are unified into a standard exception hierarchy.

Three types of batching are currently supported:

  • Graph API calls with a common http method (ie GET vs POST) and identical parameters are batched into a single graph call with ids=id1,id2,id3.
  • FQL calls are batched into a single multiquery.
  • Old REST API calls (including the query/multiquery) are batched into a single batch.run call.

See the User Guide for more information about how to use this class.

Author:
Jeff Schnitzer

FacebookBatcher

public FacebookBatcher()
Construct a batcher without an access token. All requests will be unauthenticated.

FacebookBatcher

Construct a batcher with the specified facebook access token.

Parameters:
accessToken - can be null to make unauthenticated FB requests

getMapper

public org.codehaus.jackson.map.ObjectMapper getMapper()
Get the Jackson mapper which will be used to transform all JSON responses into objects. You can change the configuration of this mapper to alter the mapping.

Sets the number of retries to execute when a timeout occurs.

setMaxBatchSize

public void setMaxBatchSize(int max)

Maximum number of things to put in a single batch. As you add more things to a single batch, the time FB takes to return it gets longer. You must balance this with timeout and retries to obtain optimum performance and reliability.

Currently this only affects graph API batching.

Default value is 30.

Parameters:
max - can be 0 to indicate unlimited.

graph

public <T> Later<T> graph(java.lang.String object,
                          java.lang.Class<T> type,
                          Param... params)
Enqueue a Graph API call. The result will be mapped into the specified class.

Parameters:
object - is the object to request, eg "me" or "1234". Doesn't need to start with "/".
type - is the type to map the result to
params - are optional parameters to pass to the method.

graph

public <T> Later<T> graph(java.lang.String object,
                          org.codehaus.jackson.type.TypeReference<T> type,
                          Param... params)
Enqueue a Graph API call. The result will be mapped into the specified type, which can be a generic collection.

Parameters:
object - is the object to request, eg "me" or "1234". Doesn't need to start with "/".
type - is the Jackson type reference to map the result to (see the BatchFB UserGuide).
params - are optional parameters to pass to the method.

graph

public Later<org.codehaus.jackson.JsonNode> graph(java.lang.String object,
                                                  Param... params)
Enqueue a Graph API call. The result will be left as a raw Jackson node type and will not be interpreted as a Java class.

Parameters:
object - is the object to request, ie "me" or "1234". Doesn't need to start with "/".
params - are optional parameters to pass to the method.

paged

public <T> PagedLater<T> paged(java.lang.String object,
                               java.lang.Class<T> type,
                               Param... params)

Enqueue a Graph API call to an endpoint that results in paginated data. Any of the Facebook "connections" fit this pattern; the results look like:

{ data:[{...},{...}], paging:{previous:"http://blahblah", next:"http://blahblah"} } The PagedLater returned from this method can be used to navigate forwards and backwards in the pagination. For example, you could have a PagedLater that provides the list of User objects plus additional PagedLater for the next and previous pages.

Parameters:
object - is the connection object to request, eg "me/friends" or "1234/feed". Doesn't need to start with "/".
type - is the type of the element that will be paged across
params - are optional parameters to pass to the method.

query

public <T> Later<java.util.List<T>> query(java.lang.String fql,
                                          java.lang.Class<T> type)
Enqueue a FQL call. The result will be interpreted as a list of the specified java class.

Parameters:
fql - is the query to run, which can include previously named query results
type - is what the contents of the resulting list will be mapped to

query

public Later<org.codehaus.jackson.node.ArrayNode> query(java.lang.String fql)
Enqueue a FQL call. The result will be left as a raw Jackson array node.

Parameters:
fql - is the query to run, which can include previously named query results

query

public <T> Later<java.util.List<T>> query(java.lang.String fql,
                                          java.lang.Class<T> type,
                                          java.lang.String queryName)
Enqueue a named FQL call. The name allows query results to be used as a parameter to further queries as described in the Facebook documentation for fql.multiquery Note: The name can only be used in further queries that are part of the same batch.

Parameters:
fql - is the query to run, which can include previously named query results
type - is what the contents of the resulting list will be mapped to
queryName - must be a unique name for the batch, used as a reference for other queries in the batch.

query

public Later<org.codehaus.jackson.node.ArrayNode> query(java.lang.String fql,
                                                        java.lang.String queryName)
Enqueue a named FQL call. The name allows query results to be used as a parameter to further queries as described in the Facebook documentation for fql.multiquery The result will be left as a Jackson array node. Note: The name can only be used in further queries that are part of the same batch.

Parameters:
fql - is the query to run, which can include previously named query results
queryName - must be a unique name for the batch, used as a reference for other queries in the batch.

queryFirst

public <T> Later<T> queryFirst(java.lang.String fql,
                               java.lang.Class<T> type)
Just like query(), but retrieves the first value from the result set. If the result set is empty, the Later.get() value will be null.

queryFirst

public Later<org.codehaus.jackson.JsonNode> queryFirst(java.lang.String fql)
Just like query(), but retrieves the first value from the result set. If the result set is empty, the Later.get() value will be null.

delete

public Later<java.lang.Boolean> delete(java.lang.String object)
Enqueue a delete call to the Graph API. Note that delete calls cannot be batched with other calls and will always result in a separate HTTP request.

post

public Later<java.lang.String> post(java.lang.String object,
                                    Param... params)
Enqueue a post (publish) call to the Graph API. Note that post calls cannot be batched with other calls and will always result in a separate HTTP request.

Parameters:
params - can include a BinaryParam to post binary objects.

oldRest

                            java.lang.Class<T> type,
                            Param... params)
Enqueue a call to the old REST API. Requires an access token.

Parameters:
methodName - is the name of the method, eg "status.get"
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if this batcher was not created with an access token

                                                    Param... params)
Enqueue a call to the old REST API. Requires an access token.

Parameters:
methodName - is the name of the method, eg "status.get"
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if this batcher was not created with an access token

execute

public void execute()
Immediately executes all queued calls with as much batching as possible. Normally there is no need to call this method explicitly; execution is triggered automatically when the first Later.get() call is made. If no calls are queued, nothing happens.
